description: The draw_geometric_shapes function generates a variety of geometric shapes and diagrams, including circles, polygons, quadrilaterals, and grids, among others. These visualizations serve as educational stimuli to facilitate understanding of various mathematical concepts, particularly in geometry.
example_usage:
# Example usage for draw_geometric_shapes
result = draw_geometric_shapes(data)

stimulus_type_specification.title: Available Images: Geometric Shapes and Diagrams
stimulus_type_specification.description: The images generated by the draw_geometric_shapes function cover a wide range of geometric concepts. They include basic shapes such as circles and polygons, as well as more complex diagrams like Venn diagrams and grids. These images can be used to illustrate concepts such as area, perimeter, and angles, as well as relationships between different shapes. The function also includes options for rotating shapes and adding labels, which can be used to further enhance understanding of geometric concepts.

details: Can illustrate concepts like area and perimeter

stimulus_type_specification.educational_purpose: The draw_geometric_shapes function serves as a powerful tool for teaching geometry. By providing visual representations of geometric concepts, it helps students to better understand these concepts and see how they are applied in practice. The ability to manipulate shapes and diagrams, such as by rotating them or adding labels, further enhances this understanding by allowing students to explore these concepts in a hands-on way. This can lead to deeper comprehension and improved retention of geometric concepts.

educational_standards.description: Distinguish between defining attributes of a shape versus non-defining attributes of a shape.
Build and draw shapes to possess defining attributes.
Recognize 2D shapes having specified attributes.
Draw shapes having specified attributes
Identify triangles.
Identify quadrilaterals.
Identify pentagons.
Identify quadrilaterals —including rhombuses, rectangles, squares, and parallelograms—by analyzing visible attributes such as number of sides, right angles, and equal-length sides.
Compare quadrilaterals to determine how shared attributes group them into larger or overlapping categories (e.g., explaining why every square is both a rectangle and a rhombus).
Recognize and describe basic geometric features: edges, vertices, parallel sides, and right angles.
Draw examples of quadrilaterals that do not fit into the subcategories of rhombuses, rectangles, or squares.
Determine if an angle is greater than, equal to, or less than a right angle.
Identify and classify quadrilaterals as parallelograms, rhombi, trapezoids, or non-parallelograms using their defining properties.
Classify triangles as right, acute, or obtuse.
Identify if a given triangle is scalene, isosceles but not equilateral, or equilateral
Classify triangles as right, acute, obtuse, scalene, isosceles but not equilateral, or equilateral.
Identify now many lines of symmetries an image, shape or letter has.
Generate a shape pattern that follows a given rule.
Understand that attributes belonging to a category of two-dimensional figures also belong to all subcategories of that category.
Select all names for a quadrilateral.
Classify polygons using Venn diagrams.
Classify triangles as equilateral, isosceles, scalene.
Find the area of rhombuses.
Solve real world problems involving the area of quadrilaterals and triangles.
